citations.narrative:
Medical records state that on December 29, 2024, a scarlet-breasted lorikeet was found water-logged and unable to fly on
the ground of the lorikeet encloser with traumatic wounds attributed to a predator attack. The right leg of the bird was
missing and there was extensive trauma to the soft tissues, skin, and muscles of the right side of the body. The animal
was humanely euthanized. This same bird previously had its left leg traumatically amputated from a predator attack in
early November of 2024.
Wild animals that gain access to the birds inside an enclosure can cause stress or injury and negatively impact their
health and well-being.
Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they protect the birds from injury. Corrected by the time
of inspection.

On December 1, 2024, a young female marabou stork was found outside of its enclosure. This bird was scheduled to be
transferred to another facility. In preparation for the transfer, the marabou stork was moved to an indoor/outdoor hospital
stall with an open outdoor top. The walls of the outdoor portion are approximately 10 feet tall. The bird was pinioned on
her left wing but was still able to get lift and escape the enclosure. A facility employee spotted the bird walking along a
facility service road behind the hospital and notified personnel who were able to recapture the bird without incident.
Enclosures that fail to safely contain birds may result in escape, injury, or death of the animal. Birds that are outside of
their enclosure are at increased risk of predation, possible restricted access to food, water, shelter, and potential non-
recovery.
Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they contain the birds securely. Corrected by the time of
inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Danisha Bullock, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
